metadata.title: Nano-wollastonite to improve fire retardancy in medium-density fiberboard (MDF) made from wood fibers and camel-thorn

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 19 April 2019 Revised 6 July 2019 Accepted 7 July 2019
KEYWORDS Camel-thorn weed; Fire properties; mineral materials; Nanotechnology; Retardants; wollastonite; wood-composite

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Chips, sawdust or other by-products of solid wood production are widely used for manufacturing wood-composite panels, but some regions suffer from a lack of suitable fiber. However, there are many other alternative lignocellulosic materials that may be suitable for these applications (Xing et al. 2007, Behling et al. 2011, Zini and Scandola 2011, Nayeri et al. 2013, 2014, Cherelli et al. 2018). Potential natural fibers such as kenaf, rice straw, and chicken-feathers have all been explored and even glass fibers have been considered (Joshi et al. 2004, Juliana et al. 2012, Taghiyari and Sarvari Samadi 2015, Taghiyari et al. 2017). While all lignocellulosic materials contain the same three polymers, varying percentages of each component or differences in cellular arrangement may affect fiber properties that then affect panel properties. Thus, any substitute must be thoroughly investigated to ensure that it is compatible with the production processes and results in a composite with acceptable properties (Taghiyari et al. 2014, 2016a, 2017). At the same time, there are opportunities to use other low-cost additives to either extend the resource or enhance specific panel properties.
Camel-thorn (Alhagi maurorum) is a native plant of Central Asia and Western Europe. It is considered an agricultural weed that competes for nutrients with crop plants. Camel-thorn is a spiny shrub that propagates via rhizomes to form large patches that exclude more valuable plants (Srivastava et al. 2014). Water resources for agricultural purposes are limited in Iran and therefore, many fields and pastures remain
uncultivated by farmers. These fields are usually over-grown by weeds during the short window of opportunity in early spring when precipitation is plentiful. Once the seasonal rain ends, weeds dry and provide some soil protection from wind, and rain, but they also consume valuable nutrients from the soil. Though camel-thorn is considered to be abundant, there are no data on the exact volume of the resource. Developing alternative uses for this material might encourage removal and help extend other fiber resources Ground Camelthorn stems have been found to be an effective extender or replacement for a portion of wood fibers in medium-density fiberboard (MDF) (Taghiyari et al. 2016a), although they also change the overall physical and mechanical properties of MDF produced.
Alternative fibers can help extend the resource, but there may be other materials and additives that can be added to reduce costs, improve resin curing, or enhance panel properties. Over the past two decades, a number of nano-materials have been tested for this purpose (Lei et al. 2008, Candan and Akbulut 2013, 2014, 2015, Kumar et al. 2013, Candan et al. 2016, Taghiyari et al. 2019a). One such additive is wollastonite, a mineral containing silicon, calcium and oxygen. Nano-wollastonite improved decay resistance as well as physical and mechanical properties of MDF panels (Lykidis et al. 2016, 2018, Sobral et al. 2017, Taghiyari et al. 2018, 2019b). Nano-materials have unique properties that can produce a variety of beneficial effects on composites (Majidi 2016, Tajvidi et al. 2016, Majidi et al. 2017, Pethig 2017, Sandeep et al. 2017, Suganya et al. 2017, Omrani et al. 2018). The present research examined the effects of nanowollastobite on fire properties of medium-density fiberboards made from mixtures of wood fibers and camel-thorn.

sections.heading: Experimental methods
sections.text:
Specimen preparation: Specimens were cut from panels produced for a previous research project (Taghiyari et al. 2016a). Briefly, a mixture of defibrillated fibers of beech (Fagus orientalis), alder (Alnus glutinosa), maple (Acer hyrcanum), hornbeam (Carpinus betulus), and different poplar species (mainly Populus nigra, Populus deltoides, and Populus euroamericana) wood were obtained locally (Sanaye Choobe Khazar Company, Iran). Camel-thorn (A. maurorum) was gathered from fields in Tehran Province. The material was airdried, ground to produce chips that averaged 8.53 mm long by 0.98 mm thick. Camel-thorn chips were added to the original wood fiber at rates of 5 or 10% (w/w) and thoroughly mixed in a rotating drum for five minutes prior to use.
Wollastonite application: Wollastonite (NW) containing at least 30% particles that were no more than 90–100 nm long with the remainder no more than 1 μm in length (Table I) was prepared from Vard Manufacturing Co. of Mineral and Industrial Products, Semnan province, Iran. NW was blended with liquid urea formaldehyde (UF) resin (solids content – 56%) for 20 min using a laboratory rotating magnet to produce a homogenous mixture. NW contents were 0, 5 or 10% w/w. MDF panels contained 10% of UF with a viscosity of 200–400 cP, 47 s of gel time, and a density of 1.277 g/ cm3 (obtained from Sari Resin Manufacturing Company, Sari, Iran) (Taghiyari et al. 2016a).
Panel manufacturing: A dry process was used to produce the MDF panels (Taghiyari et al. 2016a). UF resin was added at a rate of 10% based on the dry weight of wood fibers in all treatment panels. No hardener was used in this study. The NW/UF mixture was sprayed on the wood fibers with or without 5 or 10% camel-thorn chips (Figure 1(a,b)); the combination was then thoroughly mixed in a rotating drum before mat formation. Average moisture content at the time of hotpressing was about 7.35%. The blended fibers were manually poured into a 43 × 43 cm frame to form the mat which was then hot-pressed at 170 °C and 16 N/mm2 for 7 min to
produce 16 mm thick panels with a target density of 750 kg/ m3. Five replicate boards were made for each treatment and the panelswere conditioned at 25 (±2) °C and 45 (±3)% relative humidity for fivemonths after pressing. The outer 3 cm around the perimeter was cut from each panel and discarded. The remainder was used to prepare specimens for various tests. One fire test specimen (200 mm long, by 150 mm wide, by 16 mm thick) was cut from each of the 45 panels. The experimental design of panel groups is summarized in Table II.
Fire property tests: A Slide Fire Test Apparatus (SFTA) was designed and built, using piloted ignition following ISO Standard 11925–3 (Soltani et al. 2016, Esmailpour et al. 2018). A single-flame source was mounted on a sliding panel that moved back and forth at a measured rate of speed. Natural gas, containing 90–98% methane was used as the fuel at a rate of 5.8 liters/minute. The specimens were placed at a 45 degree angle to the burner on a holder. The time required for the specimen to develop a visible flame was measured as the “time to onset of ignition”. Similarly, the time it took for the specimen to glow was registered as the “time to onset of glowing”. At the end of the 120 s exposure, the flame was removed and the samples were allowed to continue to burn. The total time until the flame disappeared was noted as “duration of burning”. The specimens were allowed to cool, then the length and area of the burnt zone was measured. Each panel material was assessed in triplicate.
Statistical analysis: Hierarchical cluster analysis (including Dendrograms, with Ward methods and squared Euclidean distance intervals) was carried out using SPSS/18 (2010). Cluster analysis was performed to find similarities and dissimilarities between treatments using multiple properties.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Control panels with no additives ignited after 23 s of flame exposure (Table III). Addition of 5% wollastonite had no
effect on time to ignition, but addition of 10% wollastonite increased ignition time by about 15%. NW acted as a noncombustible mineral insulating layer, delaying panel ignition. Moreover, DFT analysis in a separate study suggested the formation of new bonds (Taghiyari et al. 2016b) may have resulted in better fiber integration in the MDF composite matrix. The addition of camel-thorn to the panels reduced time to onset of ignition, possibly because it was less dense than the original wood. Panels containing camel-thorn and wollastonite tended to have ignition times closer to those with camel thorn alone suggesting that the wollastonite was unable to mitigate the negative effects of the camel thorn on fire properties.
Time to onset of glow and duration of burning for woodbased MDF panels were 45 and 0.7 s, respectively. The addition of 5% camel thorn to the panels increased time to glow slightly, while addition of 10% reduced the time by almost 18%. Addition of 5 or 10% wollastonite markedly increased time to glow. Combinations of 5 or 10% camel
thorn with 5% wollastonite had no effect on time to glow compared to the wood controls, but addition of 10% wollastonite mitigated the effects of camel thorn. Similarly, duration of burning increased with addition of camel thorn, while addition of 10% wollastonite reduced duration of burning suggesting that wollastonite could mitigate the effects of camel thorn on this property.
Burnt area was lowest on the non-amended MDF and increased markedly with the addition of camel thorn. Interestingly, the addition of wollastonite alone did not reduce burnt area. Burnt area, however, can be deceptive because merely darkening the surface could result in minimal changes in panel properties, while a smaller, more intensively damaged area could have more profound effects. Panel weight loss provides a more direct measure of fire effects. As with all other properties, weight loss was lower on nonamended MDF, as well as panels amended with 5 or 10% wollastonite. The addition of camel thorn resulted in sharp increases in mass loss even when wollastonite was also present.
Cluster analysis using all the fire properties showed that the three panels with no camel-thorn were distinct from any panel containing camel-thorn chips (Figure 2) and illustrated the consistent negative effects of this material on fire properties of MDF panels. Addition of wollastonite mitigated, but could not completely overcome this effect. This indicates that panels containing camel thorn as an extender must be considered to be susceptible to fire.
Materials like camel thorn provide an attractive alternative for extending wood resources in areas where timber is scarce. Camel thorn had minimal effects on the physical and mechanical properties of the resulting MDF panels, but it had more substantial negative effects on resistance to fire. Wollastonite had a slight effect on some fire properties, but the level tested were insufficient to completely mitigate the negative impacts of camel thorn addition.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The presence of nano-wollasonite enhanced bonding, resulting in stronger MDF panels. Addition of camel thorn reduced fire resistance of MDF panels even when nano-wollastonite was added as a potential fire retardant. Nano-wollastonite acted as an insulating layer, likely limiting fire penetration into the composite matrix, but could not overcome the negative effects of the camel-thorn. The results provide a
cautionary tale about testing a variety of panel properties when contemplating substitute fiber sources.

metadata.abstractText: Wollastonite is an abundant mineral containing silicon, calcium and oxygen that has been shown to improve the properties of wood-based panels. Camel thorn (Alhagi maurorum) is a weed growing across much of Central Asia, and has relatively few commercial uses. The effects of addition of nano-wollastonite (NW) and camel-thorn chips on fire resistance of medium-density fiberboard (MDF) were assessed. Addition of 5 or 10% NW to urea-formaldehyde resin produced significant improvements in times to onset of ignition and glowing, as well as duration of burning in the panels. NW acted as a non-combustible mineral insulating layer. DFT analysis suggested that bonds between NW and wood cell-wall polymers improved overall panel properties by better integrating fibers into the composite matrix. The increased thermal conductivity caused by addition of NW also improved resin curing. Addition of 5 or 10% camel thorn chips to the resin prior to pressing negatively impacted fire properties. The results illustrate the potential for improving fire properties in MDF properties using NW. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 19 April 2019 Revised 6 July 2019 Accepted 7 July 2019
